007 * Visit http://imagingbook.com for additional details.
008 *******************************************************************************/
009
010package imagingbook.lib.image.access;
011
012import ij.process.ColorProcessor;
013import ij.process.ImageProcessor;
014import imagingbook.lib.interpolation.InterpolationMethod;
015
016/**
017 * This abstract class provides unified image access to all 4 types of images available in ImageJ:
018 * 8-bit, 16-bit, float, and color images.
019 * It is used as a wrapper around an instance of ImageJ's {@link ImageProcessor} type.
020 * <br>
021 * A generic {@link ImageAccessor} is created, e.g., by {@link #create(ImageProcessor)}, which
022 * returns an instance of {@link ByteAccessor}, {@link ShortAccessor}, {@link FloatAccessor} or
023 * {@link RgbAccessor}.
024 * {@link ImageAccessor} itself can access any ImageJ image using 
025 * the methods {@link #getPix(int, int)}, {@link #getPix(double, double)}
026 * for retrieving pixel values and {@link #setPix(int, int, float[])}
027 * to modify pixel values.
028 * All pixel values are of type {@code float[]}, either containing a single element (for
029 * scalar-valued images) or three elements (for color images).
030 * <br>
031 * In addition, the accessors for scalar-valued images ({@link ByteAccessor}, {@link ShortAccessor},
032 * {@link FloatAccessor}) provide the methods
033 * {@link ScalarAccessor#getVal(int, int)}, {@link ScalarAccessor#getVal(double, double)} and 
034 * {@link ScalarAccessor#setVal(int, int, float)}
035 * to read and write scalar-valued pixels passed as single {@code float} values.
036 * <br>
037 * The methods {@link #getPix(double, double)} and {@link ScalarAccessor#getVal(double, double)} perform interpolation at non-integer coordinates
038 * using the specified {@link InterpolationMethod}.
039 * <br>
040 * 
041 * @author W. Burger
042 * @version 2020/12/27
043 */
044public abstract class ImageAccessor {
045        
046        static final OutOfBoundsStrategy DefaultOutOfBoundsStrategy = OutOfBoundsStrategy.ZeroValues;
047        static final InterpolationMethod DefaultInterpolationMethod = InterpolationMethod.Bilinear;
048        
049        protected final ImageProcessor ip;
050        protected final int width;
051        protected final int height;
052        protected final GridIndexer2D indexer;          // implements the specified OutOfBoundsStrategy
053        protected final OutOfBoundsStrategy outOfBoundsStrategy;
054        protected final InterpolationMethod interpolationMethod;
055        
056        /**
057         * Creates a new {@code ImageAccessor} instance for the given image,
058         * using the default out-of-bounds strategy and interpolation methods.
059         * The concrete type of the returned instance depends on the specified image.
060         * 
061         * @param ip the source image
062         * @return a new {@code ImageAccessor} instance
063         */
064        public static final ImageAccessor create(ImageProcessor ip) {
065                return create(ip, DefaultOutOfBoundsStrategy, DefaultInterpolationMethod);
066        }
067        
068        /**
069         * Creates a new {@code ImageAccessor} instance for the given image,
070         * using the specified out-of-bounds strategy and interpolation methods.
071         * The concrete type of the returned instance depends on the specified image.
072         * 
073         * @param ip the source image
074         * @param obs the out-of-bounds strategy (use {@code null} for default settings)
075         * @param ipm the interpolation method (use {@code null} for default settings)
076         * @return a new {@code ImageAccessor} instance
077         */
078        public static ImageAccessor create(ImageProcessor ip,  OutOfBoundsStrategy obs, InterpolationMethod ipm) {
079                if (ip instanceof ColorProcessor) {
080                        return new RgbAccessor((ColorProcessor)ip, obs, ipm);
081                }
082                else {
083                        return ScalarAccessor.create(ip, obs, ipm);
084                }
085        }
086        
087        // constructor (used by all subtypes)
088        protected ImageAccessor(ImageProcessor ip, OutOfBoundsStrategy obs, InterpolationMethod ipm) {
089                this.ip = ip;
090                this.width  = ip.getWidth();
091                this.height = ip.getHeight();
092                this.outOfBoundsStrategy = (obs != null) ? obs : DefaultOutOfBoundsStrategy;
093                this.interpolationMethod = (ipm != null) ? ipm : DefaultInterpolationMethod;
094                this.indexer = GridIndexer2D.create(width, height, this.outOfBoundsStrategy);
095        }
096        
097        /**
098         * Returns the width of the associated image.
099         * @return the image width.
100         */
101        public int getWidth() {
102                return this.width;
103        }
104        
105        /**
106         * Returns the height of the associated image.
107         * @return the image height.
108         */
109        public int getHeight() {
110                return this.height;
111        }
112        
113        /**
114         * Returns the source {@link ImageProcessor} associated with this
115         * {@link ImageAccessor}.
116         * 
117         * @return the image processor
118         */
119        public ImageProcessor getProcessor() {
120                return this.ip;
121        }
122        
123        /**
124         * Returns the depth (number of components) of this image
125         * accessor. 1 is returned if the image is scalar-valued.
126         * 
127         * @return the image depth.
128         */
129        public abstract int getDepth();
130        
131        /**
132         * Returns the {@link OutOfBoundsStrategy} specified for this
133         * {@link ImageAccessor}.
134         * 
135         * @return the out-of-bounds strategy
136         */
137        public OutOfBoundsStrategy getOutOfBoundsStrategy() {
138                return outOfBoundsStrategy;
139        }
140
141        /**
142         * Returns the {@link InterpolationMethod} specified for this
143         * {@link ImageAccessor}.
144         * 
145         * @return the interpolation method
146         */
147        public InterpolationMethod getInterpolationMethod() {
148                return interpolationMethod;
149        }
150        
151        /**
152         * Returns the pixel value for the specified floating-point 
153         * position as a {@code float[]} with either 1 element for scalar-valued images
154         * and or more elements (e.g., 3 for for RGB images).
155         * 
156         * @param u the x-coordinate
157         * @param v the y-coordinate
158         * @return the pixel value ({@code float[]})
159         */
160        public abstract float[] getPix(int u, int v);
161        
162        /**
163         * Returns the interpolated pixel value for the specified floating-point 
164         * position as a {@code float[]} with either 1 element for scalar-valued images
165         * and or more elements (e.g., 3 for for RGB images).
166         * Interpolation is used non-integer coordinates.
167         * 
168         * @param x the x-coordinate
169         * @param y the y-coordinate
170         * @return the interpolated pixel value ({@code float[]})
171         */
172        public abstract float[] getPix(double x, double y);             // returns interpolated pixel value at real position (x, y)
173        
174        /**
175         * Sets the pixel value at the specified integer position.
176         * The new value must be provided as {@code float[]} with 
177         * 1 element for scalar-valued images or 3 elements for RGB images.
178         * @param u the x-coordinate
179         * @param v the y-coordinate
180         * @param val the new pixel value ({@code float[]})
181         */
182        public abstract void setPix(int u, int v, float[] val);
183        
184        /**
185         * Returns the value of the pixel's k-th component at the
186         * specified position. If the associated image is scalar-valued,
187         * this is equivalent to component 0.
188         * See also {@link #getDepth()}.
189         * 
190         * @param u the x-coordinate
191         * @param v the y-coordinate
192         * @param k the component index
193         * @return the component value ({@code float})
194         */
195        public abstract float getVal(int u, int v, int k);
196        
197        
198        /**
199         * Returns the interpolated value of the pixel's k-th component at the
200         * specified position. If the associated image is scalar-valued,
201         * this is equivalent to component 0.
202         * See also {@link #getDepth()}.
203         * 
204         * @param x the x-coordinate
205         * @param y the y-coordinate
206         * @param k the component index
207         * @return the interpolated component value ({@code float[]})
208         */
209        public abstract float getVal(double x, double y, int k);
210        
211        /**
212         * Sets the value of the pixel's k-th component at the
213         * specified position. If the associated image is scalar-valued,
214         * this is equivalent to component 0.
215         * See also {@link #getDepth()}.
216         * 
217         * @param u the x-coordinate
218         * @param v the y-coordinate
219         * @param k the component index
220         * @param val the new component value
221         */
222        public abstract void setVal(int u, int v, int k, float val);
223        
224        /**
225         * Returns the {@link ImageAccessor} for the k-th component;
226         * the result is a sub-type of {@link ScalarAccessor}.
227         * In the case of a scalar-valued image, THIS object is returned.
228         * 
229         * @param k the component index
230         * @return the component accessor.
231         */
232        public abstract ScalarAccessor getComponentAccessor(int k);
233        
234        // -------------------------------------------------------------------------
235        
236
237        
238}
